question.text: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">α</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">β</mi></math> be the roots of the equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>ax</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn><mo> </mo><mo>.</mo></math> Then the equation whose roots are <math><mo>-</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">α</mi><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">β</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></math> and <math><mo>-</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">α</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">β</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> is

solution.text:
α+β=-a and αβ=1
Let S and P be the sum and product of the roots of the required equation. Then,
S=-α-1β-1α-β=-(α+β)-1α+1β
=-(α+β)-α+βαβ=-(-a)--a1=2a
P=-α+1β-1α+β
=1+αβ+1αβ+1=1+1+1+1=4
So, the required equation is
x2-Sx+P=0
i.e. x2-2ax+4=0

question.text: If the roots of the quadratic equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> are  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>k</mi></mfrac></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>,</mo></math> then the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></math> is equal to

solution.text:
We have k+1k+k+2k+1=-ba ....(i)

and k+1k·k+2k+1=ca

⇒k+2k=ca

or  2k=ca-1=c-aa

or k=2ac-a .....(ii)

Now eliminate k putting the value of k in 1st  relation, we get

c+a2a+2cc+a=-ba

⇒(c+a)2+4ac=-2b(a+c)

⇒(a+c)2+2b(a+c)=-4ac

Adding b2 on both sides,

(a+b+c)2=b2-4ac

question.text: The possible values of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math> for which the equation <math><mi>n</mi><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi><mo>–</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>–</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> has roots of opposite sign is/are given by

solution.text:
D=2n–12–4nn–1=4n2+1–4n–4n2+4n=1>0
Product of roots =n-1n<0
⇒nn–1<0
⇒n∈0,1

question.text: Consider the equation <math><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, where <math><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> and <math><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mo>∈</mo><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mn>100</mn></mrow></mfenced></math>. The number of different values of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></math> so that the given equation has integral roots, is

solution.text:
x2+2x-n=0; n∈5, 100
D will be a perfect square,

 D=4+4n=41+n
⇒1+n is a perfect square
⇒1+n=9, 16, 25, 36, 49, 64, 81, 100
⇒n=8, 15, 24, 35, 48, 63, 80, 99
Therefore, 8 values are possible.

question.text: If <math><mo>-</mo><mi>π</mi><mo><</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo><</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>,</mo></math> the equation <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">cos</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">cos</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">cos</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> has more than two roots for

solution.text:
Given equation has more than two roots if it is an identity
⇒cos⁡3θ+1=0; 2cos⁡2θ-1=0 and 1-2cos⁡θ=0
⇒cos⁡3θ=-1⇒θ=±π3 which does not satisfy 2cos⁡2θ-1=0

Hence, no value possible

question.text: Let <math><mi>α</mi></math> and <math><mi>β</mi></math> are the roots of equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo> </mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>.</mo></math> If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>α</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>β</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>α</mi><mi>β</mi></math> are in arithmetic progression and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>α</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>β</mi></math> are in harmonic progression, then the value of <math><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfrac></math> is equal to

solution.text:
1, α+β,αβ are in A.P. ⇒1,-ba,ca are in A.P.
⇒1+ca=-2ba⇒a+c+2b=0 … 1
1α,12,1β are in A.P. ⇒1α+1β=1⇒α+β=αβ
⇒-ba=ca⇒b+c=0 … 2
From 1 & 2 we get,
 a=-b=c
⇒α,β are roots of equation x2-x+1=0
Now, α2+β2-2α2β22α2+β2=12-(αβ)2(α+β)2-2αβ
=12-1212-21=12+1=1.5

question.text: The number of quadratic equations that are unchanged by squaring their roots is

solution.text:
α+β=α2+β2 & αβ=α2β2⇒αβ=0 or 1 .

If αβ=0,  then let,  α=0⇒β=0 or 1 .

If β= 1 α ,

α+ 1 α = α 2 + 1 α 2 = α+ 1 α 2 −2

⇒ α+ 1 α 2 − α+ 1 α −2=0⇒α+ 1 α =2 or −1⇒α=1 or ω,  ω 2

Hence number of such equations are four 0, 0 ,  0, 1 ,  1, 1  &  ω,  ω 2

question.text: If $\alpha, \beta$ are roots of the equation $x^2+5(\sqrt{2}) x+10=0, \alpha>\beta$ and $P_n=\alpha^n-\beta^n$ for each positive integer $n$, then the value of $\left(\frac{P_{17} P_{20}+5 \sqrt{2} P_{17} P_{19}}{P_{18} P_{19}+5 \sqrt{2} P_{18}^2}\right)$ is equal to

solution.text:
Given, $x^2+5 \sqrt{2} x+10=0$
and $P_n=\alpha^n-\beta^n$

Now $\frac{P_{17} P_{20}+5 \sqrt{2} P_{17} P_{19}}{P_{18} P_{19}+5 \sqrt{2} P_{18}^2}=\frac{P_{17}\left(P_{20}+5 \sqrt{2} P_{19}\right)}{P_{18}\left(P_{19}+5 \sqrt{2} P_{18}\right)}$

$\frac{P_{17}\left(\alpha^{20}-\beta^{20}+5 \sqrt{2}\left(\alpha^{19}-\beta^{19}\right)\right)}{P_{18}\left(\alpha^{19}-\beta^{19}+5 \sqrt{2}\left(\alpha^{18}-\beta^{18}\right)\right)}$

$\frac{P_{17}\left(\alpha^{19}(\alpha+5 \sqrt{2})-\beta^{19}(\beta+5 \sqrt{2})\right)}{P_{18}\left(\alpha^{18}(\alpha+5 \sqrt{2})-\beta^{18}(\beta+5 \sqrt{2})\right)}$

Since $\alpha+5 \sqrt{2}=-10 / \alpha$ ... (1)
and $\beta+5 \sqrt{2}=-10 / \beta$ ... (2)

Now put there values in above expression
$\frac{P_{17}\left(\alpha^{19}(\alpha+5 \sqrt{2})-\beta^{19}(\beta+5 \sqrt{2})\right)}{P_{18}\left(\alpha^{18}(\alpha+5 \sqrt{2})-\beta^{18}(\beta+5 \sqrt{2})\right)}=-\frac{10 P_{17} P_{18}}{-10 P_{18} P_{17}}=1$

question.text: Let $\alpha, \beta$ are the roots of the quadratic equation $2 x^2-5 x+1=0$. If $S_n=(\alpha)^{2 n}+(\beta)^{2 n}$ then find the value of $\frac{4 S_{2021}+S_{2019}}{S_{2020}}$.

solution.text:
Given $\alpha, \beta$ are the roots of the quadratic equation $2 x^2-5 x+1=0$
Let us find an equation with roots $\alpha^2$ and $\beta^2$, let $y=x^2$, so $x=\sqrt{y}$

$2 y-5 \sqrt{y}+1=0$
$\Rightarrow 2 y+1=5 \sqrt{y}$
$\Rightarrow 4 y^2+4 y+1=25 y$
$\Rightarrow 4 y^2-21 y+1=0\left\langle_d^c\right.$

Put $\alpha^2=c$ and $\beta^2=d$
Now, $S_n=(c)^n+(d)^n$
Consider
$4 S_{2021}+S_{2019} =4\left(c^{2021}+d^{2021}\right)+c^{2019}+d^{2019}$
$=c^{2019}\left(4 c^2+1\right)+d^{2019}\left(4 d^2+1\right)$
$=c^{2019}(21 c)+d^{2019}(21 d)$
$=21 S_{2020}$
Hence, $\frac{4 S_{2021}+S_{2019}}{S_{2020}}=21$

question.text: If <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo stretchy="false">∏</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>999</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>47</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mrow></math>, then product of all real roots of <math><mi>f</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>0 </mn></math> is

solution.text:
Consider x2-47x+k=0 

For real roots, 472-4k≥0⇒k≤552

∴   k=1, 2, 3….,552

Product of real roots =1×2×3×4×…..×552=552!

question.text: If <math><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo><</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>λ</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo><</mo><mn>2</mn></math> for all <math><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>,</mo></math> then the value of <math><mi>λ</mi></math> belongs to

solution.text:
-3<x2-λx-2x2+x+1<2
⇒-3x2-3x-3<x2-λx-2<2x2+2x+2 since x2+x+1>0, ∀x∈R
⇒4x2+x3-λ+1>0,x2+x2+λ+4>0
i 4x2-xλ-3+1>0
⇒D<0⇒λ-32-4×4×1<0
⇒λ-3+4λ-3-4<0
⇒λ+1λ-7<0⇒λ∈-1,7
ii x2+xλ+2+4>0
⇒D<0⇒λ+22-4×4<0
λ+2-4λ+2+4<0λ-2λ+6<0⇒λ∈-6,2
Taking the intersection of the solutions of (i) and (ii), we get, 

 λ∈-1,2

question.text: For the equation <math><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>b</mi></math>, which of the following statements is true?

solution.text:
b<0→no solution
b=0→two solutions
0<b<4→four solutions
b=4→three solutions

question.text: If <math><mi>a</mi><mo>,</mo><mi></mi><mi>b</mi><mo>,</mo><mi></mi><mi>c</mi></math> are real numbers satisfying the condition <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0,</mn></math> then the roots of the quadratic equation <math><mn>3</mn><mi>a</mi><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> are

solution.text:
D=25b2-4×3a×7c
=25-a-c2-84ac
=25a2+c2+2ac-84ac
=25a2+c2-34ac
=17a2+c2-2ac+8a2+c2
=17a-c2+8a2+c2
D>0⇒ Roots are real and distinct

question.text: If <math><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mfrac><mrow><mn>9</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></math> and the equation <math><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> has non-real complex roots, then

options.text: <math><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mn>0</mn></math>

<math><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo><</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo><</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mn>0</mn></math>

<math><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo><</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mn>0</mn></math>

solution.text:
4a+4b+4c - 9c > 0

4a+4b - 5c > 0

fx=ax2+2bx - 5c, D < 0

f2=4a+4b - 5c > 0




a>0 and

-5c>0⇒c<0⇒a>0c<0

question.text: If the graph of the function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow></mfenced><mn>2</mn></msup><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>c</mi></mrow></mfenced><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mo>∀</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>≠</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> is strictly above the <math><mi>x</mi></math>-axis, then

solution.text:
D=B2-4AC
=2a+b-2c2-4a-b2
=4a+b-2c2-a-b2
=4a+b-2c-a+ba+b-2c+a-b
=42b-2c2a-2c
=16b-ca-c
=16c-bc-a
If c lies between a and b, then D is negative. Hence, the roots will be imaginary and the graph will be entirely above the x-axis as the coefficient of x2 is positive.

question.text: The quadratic equations <math><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and <math><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> have one root in common. The other roots of the first equation and the second equation are integers in the ratio <math><mn>4</mn><mi></mi><mo>:</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>.</mo></math> Then the common root is

solution.text:
Let, α be the common root and the other roots of the equations be 4β and 3β respectively. Then,
α+4β=6,  α4β=a
α+3β=c,  α3β=6⇒43=a6 ⇒ α=8
The first equation is x2-6x+8=0
Whose roots are 2 and 4
If α=2 ⇒β=1
So, roots of first equation is 2, 4 and that of second equation is 2, 3
If α=4⇒β=12⇒ 3β=32, 4β=2
Here the roots are not integers ⇒α=2

question.text: The value of <math><mi>k</mi></math> for which both the roots of the equation <math><mn>4</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>20</mn><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>25</mn><msup><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>15</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>66</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> are less than <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn></math>, lies in

solution.text:
Let, fx=4x2-20kx+25k2+15k-66=0……………..(i)

Let the roots of fx=0 be α, β

Since α, β are real.

∴ ∆≥0

⇒400k2-4.425k2+15k-66≥0

⇒ -15k+66≥0    ⇒    k≤225…………..ii

We have α, β<2

∴  α+β<4

⇒  --20k4<4  ⇒k<45……………iii

fx=4x-αx-β

∴      f2=42-α2-β=4++=+ve

∴  f2=16-40k+25k2+15k-66>0

⇒25k2-25k-50>0   ⇒  k2-k-2>0

⇒  k+1k-2>0   ⇒    k<-1  or k>2…………iv

Combining ii, iii & iv, we get k∈-∞,-1

question.text: The range of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></math> for which the equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> has its smaller root in the interval <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced></math> is

solution.text:
Clearly, f- 1> 0, f2< 0

since, f0=- 4 < 0

⇒ 1 - a - 4 > 0⇒ - a - 3 > 0⇒ - a > 3

or a < - 3 and 4+2a - 4 < 0

⇒ a < 0

⇒ a∈ - ∞, - 3.

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> is a polynomial of degree four with the leading coefficient one satisfying <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mn>1</mn></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced open="[" close="]"><mfrac><mrow><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mn>5</mn></mfenced></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mn>0</mn></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mn>4</mn></mfenced></mrow></mfrac></mfenced></math> (where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced open="[" close="]"><mo>·</mo></mfenced></math> represents the greatest integer function) is equal to

solution.text:
The roots of fx−x=0 are 1, 2 and 3.

So, we get,

fx−x=x−1x−2x−3x−a

For x=-1, we get,

f−1+1=−2−3−4−1−a=241+a

For x=5, we get,

f5−5=4·3·25−a=245−a

f-1+f5=23+24a+125-24a=148

For x=0, we get,

f0-0=-1-2-3-a=6a

For x=4, we get,

f4-4=3·2·1·4-a=24-6a

f0+f4=28

f-1+f5f0+f4=14828

f-1+f5f0+f4=5

question.text: Sum of the squares of all integral values of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi></math> for which the inequality <math> <mrow> <msup> <mi>x</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <mo>+</mo> <mi>a</mi> <mi>x</mi> <mo>+</mo> <msup> <mi>a</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <mo>+</mo> <mn>6</mn> <mi>a</mi> <mo><</mo> <mn>0 </mn> </mrow> </math> is satisfied for all <math> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>∈</mo> <mfenced close=")" open="(" separators=","> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mi>,</mi><mo>⁡</mo> <mn>2</mn> </mrow></mfenced></mrow></math> must be equal to

solution.text:
Let,  f⁡ x = x 2 + a x + a 2 + 6 a

∴      f(1)≤0

 

⇒      a 2 + 7 a + 1 < 0

or      - 7 - 3 5 2 < a < - 7 + 3 5 2    ....(i)

           f(2)≤0

⇒     a 2 + 8 a + 4 < 0

or   - 4 - 2 3 < a < - 4 + 2 3      ....(ii)

and        D>0

  ⇒a2-4·1a2+6a>0

⇒  a 2 + 8 a < 0

or         - 8 < a < 0         ....(iii)

From Eqs. (i), (ii) and (iii), we get,

              - 7 - 3 5 2 ≤ a ≤ - 4 + 2 3

Hence, integral values of a are  - 6 ,⁡ - 5 ,⁡ - 4 ,⁡ - 3 ,⁡ - 2 ,⁡ - 1

Required Sum

= - 6 2 + - 5 2 + - 4 2 + - 3 2 + - 2 2 + - 1 2

 = 91.

question.text: The equations <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> have exactly one root in common for

solution.text:
Let α be the common root
⇒ kα2+α+k=0
kα2+kα+1=0
On solving, we get,

 α21-k2=αk2-k=1k2-k
α2α=1-k2k2-k and α1=k2-kk2-k
⇒ α=1-k2k2-k=1⇒k2-k=1-k2
⇒ 2k2-k-1=0⇒k=-12,1
For k=1, equations are identical, thus not possible
Hence, k=-12

question.text: If the quadratic equations <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi><mfenced><mrow><mn>6</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>6</mn><mi>k</mi><mfenced><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>p</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> have both the roots common, then  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>p</mi></math> is equal to

solution.text:
(6k+2)x2+rx+3k-1=0
(12k+4)x2+px+6k-2=0 have
both roots common.

So,
6k+212k+4=rp=3k-16k-2
⇒rp=12⇒2r-p=0

question.text: If <math><mi>α</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>β</mi></math> and <math><mi>γ</mi></math> are the roots of the equation <math><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>13</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>15</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>189</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and one root exceeds the other by <math><mn>2,</mn></math> then the value of <math><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="|" open="|" separators="|"><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> is equal to

solution.text:
Let, the roots be α,β,α+2.
S1=α+β+α+2=2α+β+2=13⇒2α+β=11⇒β=11-2α
S2=αβ+βα+2+α+2α=15
⇒βα+α+2+αα+2=15
⇒11-2α2α+2+αα+2=15
⇒22α+22-4α2-4α+α2+2α=15
⇒3α2-20α-7=0⇒α-73α+1=0
⇒α=7 or -13.
α=7,β=11-2α=11-14=-3,γ=α+2=9
α=-13,β=11-2α=11+23=353,γ=α+2=53.
Since, αβγ=-189, hence we will take the first case.
α+β+γ=7+-3+9=19

question.text: If equations <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>)</mo><mo> </mo><mo>&</mo><mo> </mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> have two common roots, then value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mi>a</mi></mfrac></math> is equal to

solution.text:
x3+3x2+5x+3=0 has one root x=-1
∴x3+3x2+5x+3=(x+1)x2+2x+3
⇒a=2, b=3

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> is rational and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn><mfenced><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mn>6</mn><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>x</mi></mfrac></mrow></mfenced><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mi>,</mi><mo>⁡ </mo></math>then the product of all possible values of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> is

solution.text:
Given equation,
4 x 2 + 1 x 2 + 1 6 x + 1 x - 5 7 = 0
Let, x+1x=y;  x 2 + 1 x 2 = y 2 - 2
⇒  4 y 2 + 1 6 y - 6 5 = 0
⇒  y=-132 or⁡ 52
When,  y = 5 2
x+1x=52⇒x=2 or 12
When, y=-132
⇒  x + 1 x = - 1 3 / 2
⇒  2 x 2 + 1 3 x + 2 = 0
⇒  x = - 1 3 ± 1 5 3 4
Since x is rational, x=2 or 1 2

question.text: The sum of all real values of <math><mi>x</mi></math> satisfying the equation <math><msup><mrow><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>60</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> is

solution.text:
The given equation will be true in 3 cases.

Case 1: when x2-5x+5=1  

⇒x2-5x+4=0

⇒x=1, 4

Case 2: when x2+4x-60=0

⇒x=6, -10

Case 3: when x2-5x+5=-1 and x2+4x-60∈ even integers

Now, x2-5x+5=-1    

⇒x=2, 3

Only x=2 satisfies the given condition,

Hence, sum of all real values of x is 1+4+6-10+2=3

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>α</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>β</mi></math> are the real roots of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>log</mi><mi>x</mi></msub><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>log</mi><mi>x</mi></msub><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>log</mi><mi>x</mi></msub><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, then the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced open="|" close="|"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><msub><mi>log</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><mi>α</mi><mi>β</mi></mrow></mfrac></mfenced></math> is

solution.text:
Let logx10=t

∴t3-t2-6t=0

⇒t(t2-t-6)=0

⇒t=0,-2, 3

⇒logx10=0, -2, 3

⇒10=x0,x-2,x3

⇒x=10-12, 1013

Let α=10-12 and β=1013

Now, 1log10αβ=1log1010-16

⇒1log10αβ=-6log1010=6

question.text: The sum of the roots of the equation <math><msup><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>33</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>11</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfenced></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>22</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math> is

solution.text:
Let, t=211x
⇒211x322+211x.22=211x2.2+1
⇒t34+4t=2t2+1
⇒t3-8t2+16t-4=0
Cubic in t has roots t1,t2,t3
i.e. t1t2t3=4⇒211x1.211x2.211x3=4
⇒211x1+x2+x3=22
⇒11x1+x2+x3=2⇒x1+x2+x3=211

question.text: The number of real roots of the equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mi>x</mi></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> is equal to

solution.text:
We have, e4x-e3x-4e2x-ex+1=0

Let ex=t

t4-t3-4t2-t+1=0

⇒t2-t-4-1t+1t2=0

⇒α2-α-6=0,α=t+1t≥2

⇒α=3,-2 (reject)

⇒t+1t=3

⇒ The number of real roots =2.

question.text: If the equation in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></math> given by <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mfenced separators="|"><msup><mn>2</mn><mfenced separators="|"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><msup><mi>cos</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mfenced></msup></mfenced><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">π</mi></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mrow></mfenced><msup><mfenced separators="|"><msup><mn>2</mn><mfenced separators="|"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><msup><mi>cos</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mfenced></msup></mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">π</mi></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> has only one real solution then exhaustive set of values of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>‘</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mo>’</mo></math> is

solution.text:
Let π2cos-1x=t  ⇒  t≥2

equation becomes t2-a+12t-a2=0

has one roots 2 or greater than 2 and other root less than 2,f2≤0

⇒4-a+122-a2≤0

a2+2a-3≥0

a+3a-1≥0

a≤-3 or a≥1
